Review Bio-inspired nanostructured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts: A comprehensive review Bo Lin † Mengyang Xia † Baorong Xu Ben Chong Zihao Chen Guidong Yang * XJTU-Oxford International Joint Laboratory for Catalysis, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, Shaanxi, China XJTU-Oxford International Joint Laboratory for Catalysis School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Xi'an Jiaotong University Xi'an Shaanxi 710049 China XJTU-Oxford International Joint Laboratory for Catalysis, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, Shaanxi, China * Corresponding author. Tel: +86-29-82668658; Fax: +86-29-82665836 Tel: +86-29-82668658 Fax: +86-29-82665836 † Contributed equally to this work. As a new organic conjugated semiconductor, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is emerging as a fascinating material for various photocatalytic applications due to its adjustable electronic structure, outstanding thermal endurance, appealing chemical stability, low cost, and environmental friendliness. Nevertheless, unmodified bulk g-C3N4 possesses some intrinsic limitations related to poor crystallinity, marginal visible-light harvesting, easy recombination of charge pairs, small surface area, and slow charge migration, which give rise to the low quantum efficiency of photocatalytic reactions. One efficient strategy to overcome these shortcomings is the manipulation of the microstructures of g-C3N4. Other than the traditional structure control, mimicking the structures of creatures in nature to design and construct bio-inspired structures is a promising approach to improve the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4 and even g-C3N4-based systems. This review summarizes the recent advances of the traditional structure-control of g-C3N4-based systems, and bio-inspired synthesis of g-C3N4-based systems from two aspects of structural bionics and functional bionics. Furthermore, the fundamentals of bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based systems are introduced in detail. Additionally, the different theoretical calculations, diverse photocatalytic applications and various modification strategies of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems are recapped. We believe that this work will be a guiding star for future research in the new field of biomimetic photocatalysis. Graphical abstract This review summarizes the fundamentals and recent advances of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts, which aims to expand the knowledge on bio-inspired nanostructured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts, thus advancing the development of biomimetic photocatalysis. Keywords g-C3N4-based system Bio-inspired design Structure control Biomimetic photocatalysis Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction The sustainable development has become one of the hottest topics in human society in the last decades, due to the energy and environmental concerns. The green energy strategy focuses on the use of sustainable energies such as solar energy to reduce the consumption of fossil fuels and prevent pollution at its source, which contributes to the achievement of the goal of carbon neutrality [1–9]. To utilize solar energy, an important orientation is the development of photocatalytic technology. This green technology can convert solar energy into chemical fuels and completely degrade the overwhelming majority of organic pollutants under mild and eco-friendly conditions [10–20]. The choice of semiconductor photocatalysts is the core of such technology. Traditional inorganic photocatalysts represented by TiO2 have attracted wide attention since the end of the 20th century, due to its outstanding thermodynamic stability, low price, and nontoxicity [21–26]. Nevertheless, TiO2 is limited by the wide band gap without visible-light response (3.2 eV) and scarce active sites [27–32], thus restricting its practical implementation. Therefore, it is an urgent task for the exploration of alternative nominees with visible light response and abundant active sites, thus improving the overall photocatalytic performance. Wang et al. [33] first used an organic conjugated semiconductor material of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) as a new photocatalyst for photocatalytic H2 evolution in 2009. The polymeric-based g-C3N4 is mainly consisted of C and N atoms with numerous covalent and hydrogen bonds. It was reported that g-C3N4 has two basic building blocks, including triazine-based (C3N3) structure and tri-s-triazine/heptazine (C6N7) structure (Fig. 1 ) [34–36]. Kroke et al. [37] revealed that tri-s-triazine-based g-C3N4 by about 30 kJ mol− 1 is generally the most stable phase of C3N4 at normal temperature. Owing to the unique structural unit presented above, g-C3N4 exhibits plenty of fascinating properties, such as the capacity to use visible light (a bandgap of 2.7 eV) [38–40], adjustable electronic structure, outstanding thermal endurance (≤600 °C in air) [41–44], appealing chemical stability (insolubility in water, alkali, acid and organic solvents) [45–48], low cost, easy preparation, and environmental friendliness [49–51]. However, unmodified bulk g-C3N4 shows poor crystallinity, marginal visible-light harvesting, easily recombination of charge pairs, small surface area, and slow charge migration [52–58], which give rise to the low quantum efficiency of photocatalytic reactions. To address the challenges presented above, a lot of effort has been devoted to improving the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4. One efficient strategy gaining wide interests is the manipulation of the morphological shape of g-C3N4, because the photocatalytic reactions are the typical surface-based processes and the activity is easily influenced by the morphological changes [59,60]. The morphology control can contribute to the improved light absorption, facilitated charge separation and mass diffusion of reactant molecules, enhanced surface area and abundant active sites, thereby boosting the photocatalytic efficiency of g-C3N4 [61–66]. Till now, different traditional morphologies and structures of g-C3N4 have been constructed, including quantum dot [67,68], nanosphere [69], ball-in-ball structure [70], nanotube/nanorod/nanowire/nanofiber [71,72], nanosheet [73,74], three-dimensional ordered mesoporous/macroporous structure [75–77], three-dimensional ordered close-packed nanosphere array [78], etc. By contrast with unmodified bulk g-C3N4, these g-C3N4 photocatalysts with special structures show significantly enhanced catalytic performance. Other than the traditional structure-control tactics, mimicking the structures of creatures in nature to design and build nanostructures is another attractive route to achieve high photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4. Amazing nature provides a large number of material prototypes with different structures and functions, which can inspire researchers to design and construct various bio-inspired structured g-C3N4 with excellent photocatalytic performance. Furthermore, some bio-inspired nanostructures may endow g-C3N4 with special and novel properties. For example, Zheng et al. [79] synthesized a helical-like g-C3N4 using a template of chiral SiO2, which displayed high activity for photocatalytic water splitting and photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Concurrently, the helical-like g-C3N4 showed a novel chirality of photocatalysis due to the construction of the helical nanostructure. Our group [80] designed and synthesized a fascinating opened-up fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4. It showed an unusual spatial electron transfer property induced by the fish-scale structure, which led to a significantly enhanced photocatalytic activity for H2 evolution. Additionally, through mimicking the structures of creatures to draw on their special functions, it is expected to create similar functions for g-C3N4 to enhance its photocatalytic performance. For instance, learning from the sunflower, Qin et al. [81] designed an autonomous light-tracking photocatalytic system with the interesting phototropism, which can automatically track the direction of incident light at the range of 0°–90° to boost solar-driven photocatalytic efficiency. Owing to the fascinating advantages induced by bio-inspired structures, the design and fabrication of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4 and even g-C3N4-based composite systems have aroused extensive attentions for photocatalysis. Recently, in addition to the helical-like structure and the fish-scale-like structure mentioned above, various bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems have been reported, including honeycomb-like structure [82], flower-like structure [83], wood-like structure [84], leaf-like structure [85], and chloroplast-inspired structure [86], which advance the development of bio-inspired design related to g-C3N4-based systems. Unfortunately, there is a lack of surveys and reviews on the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based photocatalysts. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 2 , this comprehensive review is focused on the recent advances of the traditional structure-control of g-C3N4-based systems, and bio-inspired design of g-C3N4-based systems from two aspects of structural bionics and functional bionics. More importantly, the fundamentals of bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based systems are introduced in detail. Additionally, the theoretical calculations, applications and modification strategies of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems have been summarized. This review aims to offer the reference principles for the design of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems, furnish the know-how in the synthesis of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems, and provide guidance on the uncovering of the structure-activity relationships as well as catalytic mechanisms of bio-inspired nanostructured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts, thus advancing the development of biomimetic photocatalysis. 2 Traditional structure-control of g-C3N4-based system The morphology control of g-C3N4-based systems includes the traditional structure-control as well as bio-inspired design and fabrication. In order to better explain the differences between traditional structured g-C3N4-based systems and bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems as well as the importance of bio-inspired systems, it is necessary to introduce the fundamentals and latest advances of traditional structure-control of g-C3N4-based systems. Notably, the traditional structure-control strategy is widely used to boost the photocatalytic performances of g-C3N4-based systems. The common controllable structures of g-C3N4-based systems include quantum-dot structure, nanotube/nanorod/nanowire structure, nanosheet structure, nanosphere structure, three-dimensional porous structure, and three-dimensional ordered nanosphere array, etc (Fig. 3 ). The construction of these structures can improve the crystallinity, light absorption capacity, specific surface area, separation and transfer efficiency of charges, thus boosting the photocatalytic performances of g-C3N4-based systems. Now, we make a full discussion on the correlation between several main structures of g-C3N4-based systems and their photocatalytic activities in the following sections. 2.1 Quantum dot structure of g-C3N4-based system Compared with the bulk structure, when the size of materials gradually reduces to the nanometer scale, the charge transport will show a significant feature of quantum mechanics [87,88]. The materials with 0D quantum dot structure have a great surface/volume ratio, plentiful surface atoms, and unsaturated coordination state under the action of huge surface tension, which contribute to the high activity for photocatalysis [89–91]. Additionally, the absorption spectra of the quantum-dot structured materials will appear blue shift, and their band gaps will widen, thus influencing their electronic band structures in photocatalysis [92,93]. Due to the advantages of quantum-dot structure, grafting 0D quantum-dot structure on g-C3N4 is a useful route to create numerous reactive active sites as well as improve photoelectric conversion ability for boosting its photocatalytic activity. Recently, lots of quantum-dot structured g-C3N4 (CNQDs) materials have been developed [94–99], and numerous heterojunctions based on g-C3N4 quantum dots have been studied, such as CNQDs@Graphene [100], CNQDs@TiO2 fiber [101], CNQDs@SnS2 [102], Sb2S3/g-C3N4/CNQDs [103], CNQDs/Ni-Ni3C@C [104], CNQDs/Bi2Ti2O7 [105], CNQDs/Ag/Bi2MoO6 [106], CNQDs/ZnO [107]. For example, Hu et al. [108] synthesized a CNQDs/GO-InVO4 system, which included CNQDs with a diameter of about 3.0 nm (Figs. 4(a) and (b) ). The CNQDs play a significant role in the acceleration of charge transfer and the introduction of active sites, thus contributing to the promotion of photocatalytic activity in the removal of NO for the CNQDs/GO-InVO4 system. Wang et al. [109] reported g-C3N4/B-doped g-C3N4 quantum dot (BCNQDs) system, where BCNQDs has a dot-like distribution with a diameter of about 1.7 nm (Fig. 4(c)). The presence of BCNQDs is conducive to extract the photoexcited electrons from g-C3N4 to improve the photocatalytic H2 production performance (Figs. 4(d) and (e)). Nasir et al. [110] constructed a hierarchically branched TiO2/ CNQDs/SnSe2 nanosheet system (Fig. 4(f)). The CNQDs in this system act as the main photocatalyst to provide massive photogenerated charges to conduct the photocatalytic H2 evolution reaction (Fig. 4(g)). 2.2 Nanotube/nanorod/nanowire/nanofiber structure of g-C3N4-based system Recently, g-C3N4-based materials with the typical 1D nanostructures, including nanotube, nanorod, nanowire, and nanofiber, have been widely used in the fields of microelectronics, optoelectronic devices, and photocatalysis [111–116]. These 1D nanostructures can endow g-C3N4-based materials with high surface-to-volume ratio and plenty of active sites, thus contributing to superior photoconductivity, outstanding phonon and electron transport properties. At the same time, the thermal, electrical and mechanical properties of g-C3N4-based materials can also be improved due to the construction of 1D nanostructures. The 1D g-C3N4-based materials generally have a nanometer scale in the radial direction, which can reduce the diffusion distance of photoexcited charges from the volume to the surface, thus promoting the charge separation during the photocatalytic reactions. Additionally, when the 2D structured g-C3N4 curled and transformed into 1D structure, polygonal defects are likely to occur locally, thus forming the active sites and increasing the contact surface for photocatalytic reactions. So far, lots of 1D g-C3N4 g-C3N4-based systems have been developed, such as carbon QDs/g-C3N4 nanotubes [111], carbon vacancy g-C3N4 nanotube [20], oxygen-doped g-C3N4 nanorods [117], CdS/g-C3N4 nanowires [118], TiO2/g-C3N4 nanofibers [119]. For instance, Mo et al. [120] synthesized porous nitrogen-rich g-C3N4 nanotube, which displayed Lewis basicity and large surface area to promote the adsorption of CO2, thereby boosting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance. Wang et al. [121] reported Ag/g-C3N4 porous nanofibers with a high surface area and excellent visible-light absorption capacity for efficient photocatalytic H2 evolution. He et al. [122] prepared polyacrylonitrile based carbon (C-PAN)/g-C3N4 composite with a hollow cone-shaped tubular nanostructure (Figs. 5(a) and (b) ). This hollow nanotube structure can provide high surface area, enhance light harvesting, and promote the charge separation and transfer, which boost the photocatalytic H2 generation performance of C-PAN/g-C3N4 nanotube (Fig. 5(c)). Chong et al. [123] reported a system of g-C3N4 porous nanotubes/CdS nanoparticles (Fig. 5(d)). g-C3N4 porous nanotube has excellent charge mobility and high surface area, which are highly conducive to the enhancement of photocatalytic hydrogen generation performance compared to bulk g-C3N4 (Fig. 5(e)). Additionally, Zeng et al. [117] prepared 1D O-doped g-C3N4 nanorods (O-g-C3N4 NR), which displayed increased interface area, enhanced light trapping ability, and accelerated catalytic reaction for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution (Figs. 5(f)–(h)). 2.3 Nanosheet structure of g-C3N4-based system As the original morphology of g-C3N4, 2D sheet-like structure has received extensive attention [124–127]. When bulk g-C3N4 was exfoliated into 2D g-C3N4 nanosheet with single layer or few layers, the surface area of g-C3N4 is enlarged significantly, which can offer abundant adsorption active sites and reaction active sites to speed up the catalytic reactions. Furthermore, the ultrathin nanosheet structure can endow g-C3N4 with massive shorter electron/hole migration paths, which is conducive to the charge transfer to the g-C3N4 surface and the acceleration of photocatalytic reaction process. Nowadays, various systems based on g-C3N4 nanosheets have been constructed, such as 0D/2D Ni2P QDs/g-C3N4 [128], 0D/2D Bi2MoO6/g-C3N4 [129], 0D/2D Cu2–x S/g-C3N4 [130], 2D/2D WO3/g-C3N4 [131], 2D/2D MoS2/g-C3N4 [132], 2D/2D Fe2O3/g-C3N4 [133], 2D/2D ZnIn2S4/g-C3N4 [134], 2D/3D/2D rGO/Fe2O3/g-C3N4 [135], 2D/3D g-C3N4@ZnO [136], 2D/3D g-C3N4/UiO-66 [137]. For example, Yang et al. [138] reported few-layer polymer carbon-nitrogen nanosheets (PCN-U) with a thickness of about 1.2 nm using urea as the precursor (Figs. 6(a) and (b) ). By contrast with bulk PCN-U, the shift of CB and VB related to PCN-U nanosheets contributes to a stronger thermodynamic driving force for photocatalytic H2 generation (Fig. 6(c)). Owing to the effect of unique 2D thin structure, PCN-U shows increased active sites and accelerated charge separation, thus leading to an enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen generation rate of 169.5 μmol·h−1 (Fig. 6(d)). Li et al. [139] prepared atomically thick g-C3N4 nanosheet (CRed-AT-C3N4) with some nanoscale pores (Fig. 6(e)). The atomically thick nanosheet structure can endow g-C3N4 with the synergistic advantages, including enlarged surface area, boosted diffusion of reactants, and accelerated charge separation, thereby yielding an enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate of 246.2 μmol·h−1 for CRed-AT-C3N4 (Fig. 6(f)). Zhou et al. [140] prepared ultrathin g-C3N4 nanosheet with hierarchical pores (P-mMCNNS-25) for photocatalytic H2O2 production. P-mMCNNS-25 possesses layered porous nanosheet microstructure with a uniform pore distribution between 10 and 100 nm and a thickness of 3 nm (Fig. 6(g)). Due to the construction of the porous nanosheet structure, some carbon defects were introduced in P-mMCNNS-25 (Fig. 6(h)), thus contributing to the enhanced charge separation efficiency and improved photocatalytic H2O2 yield via the route of two e− reduction (Fig. 6(i)). 2.4 Nanosphere structure of g-C3N4-based system g-C3N4-based systems with spherical structures have been widely used in various fields, such as drug delivery, optics, energy storage, and catalysis [141–143]. Recently, through the morphology control strategy, a series of complex spherical nanostructures have been derived, such as Fe3O4/g-C3N4 nanospheres [144], MoS2/Ti3+-TiO2/g-C3N4 hollow nanosphere [145], TiO2@Pt@C3N4 hollow spheres [146]. In these reported photocatalytsts with the hollow nanosphere structure, this structure has a mesoporous shell and a controllable cavity, which could be used as a special photoreactor to improve the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4-based systems. This special photoreactor shows many advantages in photocatalysis. Firstly, when the photocatalytic reactions begin, the incident light is scattered and redirected to various directions in the inner space of the sphere-like photoreactor, thus significantly improving the light absorption efficiency of g-C3N4-based system [147]. More importantly, the hollow structure is beneficial to enrichment of reaction molecules, acceleration of charge migration, and introduction of active sites, thereby leading to a significant promotion of photocatalytic activity for g-C3N4-based systems [148]. For instance, Zheng et al. [149] developed a Janus Co3O4 nanoparticle/hollow carbon nitride sphere/Pt nanoparticle (Co3O4/HCNS/Pt) system (Figs. 7(a) and (b) ). In this system, the hollow spherical structure not only can provide large surface area to accelerate the adsorption and conversion of water molecules, but facilitate the charge migration, thus contributing to an improvement of photocatalytic water-splitting performance. Our group [70] reported a novel ball-in-ball structured g-C3N4@SiO2 (BSGSCN) (Fig. 7(c)), which has a well mesoporous shell and a core with a thickness of about 35 nm (Fig. 7(d)). The construction of ball-in-ball structure can endow g-C3N4 with many advantages, including efficient enrichment of reactant molecules, enhanced light harvesting, increased active surface area, and higher degree of crystallinity, thus contributing to the improved photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance (Fig. 7(e)). Additionally, Si et al. [150] prepared nanoporous g-C3N4 microspheres (Np-CNM, Fig. 7(f)). With the construction of nanoporous microsphere, the capacity of charge separation and transfer is improved, which is in favor of the promotion of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate for g-C3N4 (Fig. 7(g)). 2.5 Three-dimensional porous structure of g-C3N4-based system The unique three-dimensional network-like porous structure is a fascinating microstructure for the structure design of g-C3N4-based systems. Generally, three-dimensional porous structured photocatalysts have numerous advantages [153–161]: (1) High surface area can furnish abundant adsorption and reaction active sites, thus facilitating the photocatalytic reactions; (2) Three-dimensional porous structure can lead to the multiple scattering and reflection effects to improve the light absorption; (3) The catalysts are fixed in three-dimensional network, thus avoiding the loss of catalysts and improving the stability; (4) Three-dimensional network structure can stabilize the intermediate products and promote the desorption of final products. For example, our group [76] reported a CoP/three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) g-C3N4/Au system. Its shows excellent charge separation efficiency and high photocatalytic H2 evolution rate of 11820.1 μmol·g−1·h−1, up to 619.9 times higher than that of 3DOM g-C3N4. Bi et al. [162] prepared Au/3DOM g-C3N4/Cd(0.58)Zn(0.42)S system. Owing to the intimate interfacial contacts and the uniform wall thickness of 3DOM frame, Au/3DOM g-C3N4/Cd(0.58)Zn(0.42)S can harvest a wider range of visible light, thus exhibiting outstanding photocatalytic activity for H2 genaration and RhB degradation. Besides, the periodic hierarchical structured g-C3N4 possesses large surface area and numerous defect sites, thus providing a large number of adsorption sites for the reactant molecules in the photocatalytic reaction. Our group [78] reported a three-dimensional ordered arranged g-C3N4 nanosphere arrays (CNAs), which displays 3D ordered closed face-centered cubic array structure (Figs. 8(a) and (b) ). Through adjusting the stacking-layer-number of g-C3N4 nanosphere arrays, the number of point defects can be controlled, which is related to the water-adsorption capacity. Notably, CNA2 with the optimal water-adsorption capacity displays a high photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate (HER) of 156.9 μmol·h−1, which is 21.2 times higher than of pure g-C3N4 (Fig. 8(c)). Ai et al. [151] reported MnO x -decorated three-dimensional porous structured g-C3N4 (MSCN) (Fig. 8(d)). Owing to the construction of three-dimensional porous structure, the HER value of MSCN is about 18 times higher than that of bulk g-C3N4 (Fig. 8(e)). Cao et al. [152] synthesized 2D/3D Ni(OH)2/g-C3N4 system (Ni/DOMCN, Fig. 8(f)). In this system, numerous uniform nanopores are interconnected throughout the 3D g-C3N4 (Fig. 8(g)), which can increase active sites and promote the transfer of species during the catalytic process, thus leading to the enhancement of HER related to 25-Ni/DOMCN (Fig. 8(h)). Based on the descriptions and comments mentioned above, a summary of traditional structure-control of g-C3N4-based systems for diverse photocatalytic applications is shown in Table 1 , including the synthetic methods, advantages and disadvantages of different traditional structure-control strategies related to g-C3N4-based system. Through these descriptions and summary, it can be found that the traditional structure-control plays an indispensable role in modulating light-absorption capacity, charge separation and transfer efficiency, and active surface area, thus influencing the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based systems. This discovery is expected to provide a foundations and supplements for researchers in the aspect of the morphology manipulation, which is beneficial to the follow-up introduction of bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system. 3 Bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system Apart from the traditional structure control tactics, learning from the structures of creatures (including animals, plants, and microorganisms) in nature is a promising approach to the effective structure design of g-C3N4-based systems, which contributes to acquire unification and harmonization between structure and functionality. More importantly, through investigating the structures and properties of creatures, the bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system provides new design ideas and working principles for various photocatalytic reactions. This chapter focuses on the fundamentals of bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system for photocatalysis. It properly consists of four parts, including the design principles for bio-inspired fabrication of g-C3N4-based system, the synthesis strategies of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system, the unique photocatalytic mechanisms of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system, and the advantages and disadvantages related to bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system. 3.1 The design principles for bio-inspired fabrication of g-C3N4-based system When constructing the bio-inspired nanostructured g-C3N4-based systems, it is suggested to consider the scientific problems that affect the photocatalytic activity. Notably, the performances of photocatalytic reactions have long relied on boosting the surface redox reaction as well as promoting the separation and migration of photogenerated electron-hole pairs (namely charge carriers) [163,164]. In terms of improving the surface redox reaction, large surface area with plenty of active sites can accelerate the processes of mass transfer, adsorption, reaction, and desorption, thus boosting the overall photocatalytic reaction efficiency. Therefore, it is advisable to construct the 2D sheet-like structure with large surface area for the design of high-efficiency g-C3N4-based system. Moreover, to suppress the recombination of charge carriers, on the one hand, the more and shorter charge transfer routes are necessary. One effective route is the construction of 2D sheet-like structure with the small thickness to facilitate charge separation. On the other hand, the driving force for charge separation is also necessary. As previously reported [80,165], the opened-up sheet-like structure with sharp edges can endow g-C3N4-based system with a strong driving force, which leads to fast charge collection at the tips/edges, similarly to the working principle of ‘lightning rod effect’, thus boosting the charge separation and transfer significantly. Based on all considerations mentioned above, to acquire the high photocatalytic activity, it is a promising route to design and construct bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems that have opened-up thin-sheet-like structures with sharp edges and large surface area, just like flower-like structure and fish-scale-like structure. The synthesis of flower-like structure or fish-scale-like structure usually requires the precisely controlled solvothermal conditions or high-temperature annealing with the assistance of various surfactants or templates. Additionally, in some photocatalytic reactions, such as photocatalytic water-splitting for H2 and O2 evolution, photooxidation and photoreduction are locally incompatible, so the two kinds of reaction must be strictly separated in the nanospace [166]. As we all know, in the thylakoid membrane of the chloroplast, functional proteins and electron carriers are precisely arranged on both sides of the membrane. Through charge separation and electron transport chains, sunlight is effectively converted into chemical potential for oxygen production and CO2 fixation [165,167–170]. Therefore, it is an effective pathway to mimic the function zones of the chloroplast to design and fabricate g-C3N4-based system for photocatalysis. One attempt is the loading of different active components in the different spatial positions of a support in the designed system via the charge attachment method [86,171] or compartmental dual-cocatalyst-loading method [149,172], thus providing the stable microenvironment and guaranteeing the implementation for two kinds of reactions. 3.2 The synthesis strategies of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system Various synthesis methods of bio-inspired g-C3N4 system have been developed, mainly including thermal condensation method, soft template method, hard template method and supramolecular self-assembly method. The thermal condensation method is easy to operate, efficient, and suitable for large-scale production of bio-inspired structure g-C3N4 photocatalysts. However, this method can hardly realize the accurate control of the size and morphology of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4 system. Taking bio-inspired honeycomb-like structured g-C3N4 as an example, Wang et al. [173] prepared honeycomb-like g-C3N4 using urea and water as the raw materials through the thermal condensation method with a simple calcination at 450 °C, however, there is still room for improvement in the regularity of the morphology for honeycomb-like g-C3N4. Zhou et al. [174] synthesized honeycomb-like structured g-C3N4 nanosheets via facile thermal condensation of melamine/NH4Cl mixture, and these nanosheets are slightly agglomerated. In terms of the soft templating method, surfactants are usually used in this method, mainly including ordered polymers formed by amphiphilic molecules, such as micelles, and microemulsions, etc. Weak intermolecular or intramolecular interactions can drive the precursor molecules to form aggregates with different spatial structural characteristics, thereby obtaining nanomaterials with specific morphology. The soft template method is easy to construct diverse bio-inspired structured g-C3N4 systems without the complicated equipment, however, this method may introduce some impurities in the as-prepared bio-inspired photocatalysts. For example, our group [80] used CTAB and PVP as the porogens to realize the transformation from g-C3N4 nanosheets to bio-inspired fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4 nanosheets. Besides, the hard template method is widely applied to the construction of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system. g-C3N4 photocatalysts with specific bionic structures can be obtained using porous silicon, metal templates and molecular sieves with different spatial structures. For instance, Zheng et al. [175] prepared bio-inspired helical-like structured g-C3N4 using a chiral mesoporous silica with the spiral hexagonal rod-like morphology as the sacrificial template. Tong et al. [176] prepared thylakoid-inspired g-C3N4 nanocapsules using the hard template of SiO2 with different shells, which have a variety of mesoporous shells and hollow cavities, similarly to the structure of stacked and interconnected thylakoids. Compared with the soft template, the hard template not only has excellent stability and narrow-space limit effect, but also can strictly control the size and morphology of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system. However, the structure of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system is easily damaged when the hard template is removed. Additionally, for the supramolecular self-assembly method, the supramolecular assembly usually relies on at least two kinds of precursor molecules, which join together through intermolecular interactions to form complex organized aggregates. For instance, Zhang et al. [85] reported a bio-inspired vine-like structured g-C3N4 via the supramolecular self-assembly of urea molecules and dicyandiamide-formaldehyde resin. The supramolecular self-assembly shows some new properties and functions by contrast with individual molecules or lower molecular aggregates. Nevertheless, this method requires high match among different types of precursor molecules to form supramolecular assembly, which limits its application in the synthesis of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4 system. 3.3 The unique photocatalytic mechanisms of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system Unlike the routine photocatalytic mechanisms related to the traditional structured g-C3N4-based systems, the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems shows some unique photocatalytic mechanisms when the photocatalytic reactions have been conducted. Firstly, some bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems have opened-up sheet-like structures with sharp edges, just like fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4. This fish-scale-like structure can endow g-C3N4 with the unusual spatial electron transfer property, which means the photoexcited electrons can selectively transfer towards the edges of the fish-scale-like slices along the plane direction, then gather at the sharp edge regions, thus boosting charge separation efficiency and photocatalytic activity significantly [80]. Secondly, in the chloroplast-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems, the construction of strictly separated zones for two different reactions can enhance the photocatalytic performance. For example, a Janus Co3O4/hollow carbon nitride spheres (HCNS)/Pt system allows the interior and exterior surface of HCNS to be loaded separately with Pt (the reduction center) and Co3O4 (the oxidation center) [149]. The spatially separated reduction centers and oxidation centers conduct the photocatalytic reactions of H2 evolution and O2 evolution, respectively, thereby suppressing the undesired reverse reaction for water splitting and restraining the charge recombination. Additionally, some special bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems represented by the helical-like g-C3N4 showed an extraordinary mechanism when the photocatalytic reaction was conducted. The helical-like g-C3N4 displays unequal quantities of left-handed and right-handed helical nanostructures [175]. This helical-like nanostructure can lead to an asymmetric electric field. Under this asymmetric field, the electronic transitions of g-C3N4 may lead to the optical activity to circularly polarized light [177]. Therefore, the helical-like structured g-C3N4 is expected to be a photocatalyst for the enantioselective synthesis of organic compounds. 3.4 The advantages and disadvantages for bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system As shown in Fig. 9 , by contrast with the traditional structure-control of g-C3N4-based system, the bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system shows some advantages. Firstly, the type of traditional structured g-C3N4-based systems is relatively limited. However, for bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based system, nature can provide abundant material prototypes to inspire researchers to design and construct the bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based system. If well developed, numerous different types of potential bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems may be designed and fabricated in the near future. Moreover, certain functions of some creatures are superior to that of the artificially manufactured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts, such as the photosynthesis of chloroplasts for using solar energy. Therefore, we can design and construct bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems with the similar working principles and reaction mechanisms to the targeted creatures, thus improving photocatalytic activity and selectivity. Additionally, through the route of bio-inspired design and fabrication, some bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems can gain special and novel properties, such as the unique optical activity related to helical-like structured g-C3N4, and the unusual spatial electron transfer property related to fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4. However, the bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system still remains a few challenges in combination with the traditional structure-control. Firstly, the structural order and regularity for bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems need to be improved. Secondly, the structure-activity relationship and photocatalytic mechanism of some bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems are unclear. More importantly, the research on bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based system for photocatalysis is still in the initial stage, so massive potential bio-inspired structures of g-C3N4-based system need to be developed urgently. Based on the overview on the fundamentals of bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based photocatalysts, we hope that the follow-up researchers can learn about the biomimetic photocatalysis and get some inspiration for the biomimetic design of g-C3N4-based systems. Taking the bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based systems as a breakthrough, it is likely to develop the new field of biomimetic photocatalysis. 4 Structural bionics of g-C3N4-based system A growing number of researches have emerged to construct artificial g-C3N4-based systems based on the ideas of structural bionics, such as honeycomb-like structure, flower-like structure, fish-scale-like structure, leaf-like structure, and helical-like structure. These bio-inspired nanostructures significantly enhance the photocatalytic performances of g-C3N4-based systems through the manipulation of photon-trapping capacity, exposed active edges and active sites as well as charge migration capacity. Herein, we discuss the effect of structural bionics related to g-C3N4-based systems on the photocatalytic performance in the following sections. 4.1 Bio-inspired honeycomb-like structure of g-C3N4-based system Inspired by the multi-cavity honeycomb structure of bees in nature, diverse honeycomb-like structured g-C3N4-based systems have been developed. This bio-inspired structure endows g-C3N4-based systems with larger surface area, excellent visible-light absorption capacity, higher electron donor density, faster diffusion of reactant molecules, and promoted charge separation compared to bulk g-C3N4 [178–182]. Wang et al. [173] prepared honeycomb-like g-C3N4 using urea and water as the raw material through condensation at 450 °C (Fig. 10(a) ). The honeycomb-like g-C3N4 shows high photocatalytic activity with a NO removal rate of 48% (Fig. 10(b)). The unique honeycomb-like structure leads to the significantly accelerated charge separation and prolonged radiative lifetime of charges for g-C3N4, which is related to the abundant exposed active edges of g-C3N4 nanosheets. Zhou et al. [174] synthesized thin-shelled honeycomb-like structured g-C3N4 (MAC-8-550) via facile co-pyrolysis of melamine/NH4Cl mixture (Fig. 10(c)). MAC-8-550 with Pt as the cocatalyst showed enhanced photoactivity for H2 generation with an apparent quantum efficiency of 9.86% at 420 ± 10 nm, again indicating the advantages of the honeycomb-like structure on boosting photocatalytic activity. Yang et al. [183] reported a honeycomb structured g-C3N4 with the tunable band structure (Fig. 10(d)). Its photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate is about 5.2 times higher than that of original g-C3N4 (Fig. 10(e)). The formation of the honeycomb structure can efficiently improve light absorption via the multiple scattering effect of the incident light, facilitate the mass diffusion of reactants, improved charge separation efficiency, thereby improving the photocatalytic H2 production performance of g-C3N4 (Fig. 10(f)). Xiao et al. [82] prepared honeycomb porous g-C3N4 (PGCN) via a simple template-free method (Fig. 10(g)). Through controlling the honeycomb porous structure of PGCN, BET surface area and of PGCN is tuned, which is associated with the amount of surface defects. As a result, the sample of PGCN-3 with the appropriate amount of surface defects shows significantly enhanced photocatalytic decomposition activity of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA) under visible-light irradiation than bulk g-C3N4 (Figs. 10(h) and (i)). Huang et al. [184] reported a honeycomb-like structured g-C3N4 with large surface area and high porosity using cyanuric acid, urea and melamine as the precursors. The introduction of cyanuric acid and urea optimizes the structural units of honeycomb-like g-C3N4 to suppress the recombination of interior charges, thus leading to a significant improvement of photocatalytic degradation efficiency over bulk g-C3N4. 4.2 Bio-inspired flower-like structure of g-C3N4-based system Similarly to the honeycomb structure, the bio-inspired flower-like structure has multi-layered and hierarchical features, which can endow g-C3N4-based system with large specific surface area and excellent stability. Up to now, a large number of bio-inspired flower-like structured g-C3N4-based systems have been constructed [185–191]. For example, Yang et al. [192] synthesized P-doped g-C3N4 microflowers with high specific surface area and high porosity using a simple thermal copolymerization method (Fig. 11(a) ). The as-prepared g-C3N4 microflowers are composed of ultrathin nanosheets with abundant mesopores (Figs. 11(b) and (c)). The unique flower-like structure combined with the doping of P heteroatoms realize the optimization of the visible-light harvesting capacity and charge mobility efficiency, thus leading to outstanding photocatalytic H2 evolution rate of 256.4 μmol·g−1·h−1 for flower-like P-doped g-C3N4, almost 24 times higher than that of pure g-C3N4 (Fig. 11(d)). Wang et al. [83] reported flower-like Mo-doped g-C3N4 through a green method of biological template (Fig. 11(e)). The optimal flower-like Mo-doped g-C3N4 sample (CN-Mo0.2) exhibits an excellent hydrogen evolution rate of 2008.9 μmol·g−1·h−1 (Fig. 11(f)), which is related to the massive catalytically active edges induced by the flower-like structure and the optimized band structure induced be the Mo doping (Fig. 11(g)). 4.3 Bio-inspired fish-scale-like structure of g-C3N4-based system Inspired by the structure of fish-scale in nature, it is interesting to construct fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4 nanosheets. This unique fish-scale-like structure can endow g-C3N4 with multiple advantages. Firstly, a large number of pores are generated in the fish-scale-like frame, thereby introducing abundant light-absorbing active sites to effectively capture photons. Secondly, the spatial arrangement of fish-scale-like slices can produce the multiple scattering and reflecting effects, thus extending the light residence time and improving the light absorption efficiency. More importantly, the photoexcited electrons can selectively transfer to the edges of the fish-scale-like slices along the plane direction, which greatly improves the charge separation efficiency [80]. Our group [80] first reported unique fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4 nanosheets. As shown in Fig. 12(a) , g-C3N4 nanosheets are obtained under high-temperature heat treatment. Subsequently, using PVP and CTAB as the porogens, g-C3N4 nanosheets are transformed into fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4 nanosheets (FSGN) with an average scale width of 120 nm under solvothermal conditions (Fig. 12(b)). It is noted that the opened-up fish-scale-like structure enables the photoexcited electrons to transfer along the plane of the fish-scale-like slices and gather at the edge areas of the fish-scale-like slices, similarly to the working principles of the lightning rods (Fig. 12(c)). Such structure-induced characteristics of selective electron transfer can promote charge separation and transfer significantly, contributing to a greatly prolonged radiation lifetime of charges (Fig. 12(d)). As expected, the fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4 nanosheets show an enhanced photocatalytic H2 generation rate of 1316.35 μmol·g−1·h−1, up to 20 times and 2.93 times compared to bulk g-C3N4 and g-C3N4 exfoliated nanosheets, respectively (Fig. 12(e)). This discovery provides a platform for the design of g-C3N4 photocatalysts with efficient charge separation. Besides, Liang et al. [193] reported the fish-scale-like structured carbon-nitrogen based tubular system (ZnIn2S4/FTCNso) for photocatalytic degradation of tetracycline (Fig. 13(a) ). By contrast with pure CN (14%) and ZnIn2S4 (17%), the degradation efficiency of 5% ZnIn2S4/FTCNso can reach 74% under visible-light illumination (Fig. 13(b)). This is because the abundant pores and structural defects of fish-scale-like g-C3N4 are conducive to the charge transfer (Fig. 13(c)). Yang et al. [194] prepared a new type of Ag3PO4/fish-scale-like g-C3N4 photocatalyst. The construction of fish-scale-like structured g-C3N4 in composite catalyst is beneficial to the charge mobility and the inhibition of charge recombination (Figs. 13(d) and (e)). The optimal Ag3PO4/fish-scale-like g-C3N4 composite (AC-200) shows significantly enhanced oxygen evolution activity under light-emitting diode (LED) illumination, much higher than that of the hybridized Ag3PO4/g-C3N4 composite (AC*-200) (Fig. 13(f)). 4.4 Bio-inspired leaf-like structure of g-C3N4-based system Bio-inspired leaf-like structure is also an interesting nanostructure to enhance the light absorption and introduce abundant active edges and sites, thus boosting the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4-based system [195,196]. Zhang et al. [85] developed leaf-like g-C3N4 (V-CN) through copolymerizing urea with dicyandiamide-formaldehyde resin, which has a complex curled structure with an average size of less than 200 nm (Figs. 14(a) and (b) ). The g-C3N4 flakes are rolled up and do not block each other, displaying an arrangement similarly to a leaf mosaic, leading to effective light capture. The leaf-like structure endows V-CN with improved light utilization rate and large surface area, thus leading to a high photocatalytic hydrogen yield (13.6 mmol·g−1·h−1, Fig. 14(c)) under visible-light irradiation, and the apparent quantum yield at 420 nm is 12.7%, up to 38 times higher than that of original g-C3N4. Feng et al. [197] synthesized a leaf-vein-like g-C3N4 as an efficient photocatalyst for H2O2 evolution. The obtained CN4 sample displays a vein-like structure with tunable light absorption (Fig. 14(d)), enhanced charge-transfer capacity, and massive exposed active sites, thus leading to a H2O2 yield of 287 µmol·h−1 and an apparent quantum yield of 27.8% at 420 nm (Fig. 14(e)). CN4 show the highly selective two-electron (two-step) H2O2 evolution owing to the reinforcement processes of ·O2 − production and the conversion from ·O2 − to H2O2 (Fig. 14(f)). These leaf-like structured g-C3N4-based systems are suitable as the frames to grow single-atom or molecular cocatalysts for photocatalysis. 4.5 Bio-inspired helical-like structure of g-C3N4-based system The fascinating helical structure has become one hotspot in the design of bio-inspired structures related to g-C3N4-based system. This helical structure can not only endow g-C3N4-based system with optimized morphology, unique chirality and optical activity, but also facilitate the charge transfer along the axis and introduce more active sites [198,199]. For example, Zheng et al. [175] reported helical-like structured g-C3N4 (HR-CN) using a sacrificial template of chiral mesoporous silica (CMS) with a spiral hexagonal rod-like morphology and an ordered channel around the rod-like central axis (Fig. 15(a) ). The SEM image (Fig. 15(b)) shows that HR-CN has a uniform, monodisperse and twisted hexagonal rod-like morphology with an outer diameter of about 100–200 nm. Due to the helical-like structure, HR-CN shows the optical activity to the circularly polarized light on the semiconductor absorption edge, thereby leading to significantly improved photocatalytic activity. Chen et al. [200] prepared helical-like structured BiVO4/Ag/C3N4 as an efficient photocatalyst for selective oxidation of low hydrocarbons (Figs. 15(c) and (d)). Due to the unique helical-like structure, the BiVO4/Ag/C3N4 composite shows excellent light absorption capacity and high exposure rate of active sites. Besides, the helical BiVO4/Ag/C3N4 has suitable sites for photocatalytic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes and ketones, which leads to excellent selectivity in the oxidation of alkanes (Fig. 15(e)). It can be seen from these researches that the helical-like structured g-C3N4 is a promising candidate for the enantioselective synthesis of organic compounds. To sum up, the structural bionics provides a promising approach to link the biomimicry and g-C3N4-based photocatalysts, thereby achieving high photocatalytic performances. However, most researches on the structurally biomimetic g-C3N4-based photocatalysts only value the similarity in morphology, and ignore the intrinsic connection between bio-inspired structures and photocatalytic performances. Therefore, the uncovering of structure-activity relationship of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems need to be resolved. 5 Functional bionics of g-C3N4-based system Except for the structural bionics of g-C3N4-based system, the functional bionics is another important aspect for the bio-inspired design of g-C3N4-based system. Functional bionics means that mimicking the structures of creatures in nature is to draw on their special functions to create similar functions for g-C3N4-based system. Functional bionics is an effective means to boost the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based system via the introduction of new functions. This chapter focuses on the two typical bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems based on the functional bionics, including wood-like structure, and chloroplast-inspired structure. 5.1 Bio-inspired wood-like structure of g-C3N4-based system In natural wood, lignin and hemicellulose are filled among cellulose microfibers (Fig. 16(a) ), thus improving excellent mechanical stiffness and strength of the cell wall [84,201]. The hierarchical porous structure of the natural wood can provide opportunities for the multi-phase transfer of fluids, ions and gases, as well as the multi-spectral energy transport of phonons, photons and microwaves, leading to numerous interesting physical and chemical properties. Therefore, mimicking the structure of natural wood to design the wood-like structured g-C3N4-based system is a promising way to boost its photocatalytic activity. For instance, inspired by the wood structure, Jiang et al. [84] constructed vertically arranged and hierarchical porous g-C3N4/carbon nanotube arrays (g-C3N4/CNT) using a vertical 3D printing strategy with lignin as the binder. The 2D layered g-C3N4 structure is assembled into a vertical array with a micro-porous structure (Figs. 16(b) and (c)). As shown in Fig. 16(d), the carbon nanotubes are uniformly coated on the surface of g-C3N4, and they are entangled with each other to form a cross-linked framework. Under the light illumination, the multiple scattering occurred on the vertically aligned g-C3N4/CNT arrays with the hierarchical structures, thus improving light harvesting ability (Fig. 16(e)). Besides, massive surficial active sites arising from vertically aligned and hierarchically porous structure are in favor of the adsorption and reaction of reactant molecules. The improved light absorption and plenty of surficial active sites lead to the enhanced H2 evolution activity for printed g-C3N4/CNT array. Wu et al. [202] prepared g-C3N4@wood-derived carbon (g-C3N4@WDC) with a micro-nanoscale ordered interconnected porous structure via a simple two-step process of immersion and carbonization. g-C3N4@WDC has a large number of internal channels in the axial and radial interconnection network system, where g-C3N4 is evenly distributed on the outer surface and inner hole of WDC (Fig. 16(f)). The ordered hierarchical porous structure of g-C3N4@WDC boosts the light harvesting and the charge transport, thus contributing to enhanced photocatalytic degradation efficiency of MB (Fig. 16(g)). It is worth noting that the wood-like structure is a complex structure. The construction of bio-inspired wood-like structure requires the rational design of multiple parameters, such as the composition, morphology and spatial distribution related to active components and supports, exposed surface area, the refraction and reflection of incident light in the wood-like system, the transport distance to the surface for internal photogenerated charges, structural stability, etc. 5.2 Chloroplast-inspired structure of g-C3N4-based system In addition to the wood-like structure, inspired by the photosynthesis of chloroplasts in natural plants, hierarchical g-C3N4-based system can be designed via simulating the structure of thylakoids, thereby boosting the utilization of light, accelerating charge transfer and improving photocatalytic performance. For example, inspired by the highly integrated functions of thylakoids in the natural photosynthesis system, Tong et al. [176] prepared g-C3N4 (MSCN) nanocapsules photocatalysts using SiO2 hard templates with different shells. MSCN has a variety of mesoporous shells and hollow cavities. These shells divide the lumens into space-constrained nanoscale reactors, similarly to the structure of stacked and interconnected thylakoids, thus enhancing light collection and charge transfer from the entity to the surface. Among different samples, the triple-shell g-C3N4 (TSCN) nanocapsules have excellent visible-light capture and electron transfer capacity, thus leading to excellent photocatalytic activity compared to single-shell and double-shell nanocapsules. This is because as the number of shell layer increases, the light-harvesting ability of g-C3N4 is greatly enhanced. The multiple scattering and reflection of the incident light in the multi-shell nanostructure and the transmission of light in the porous thin shell promote the absorption of the entire visible light range, and the reduction of the quantum size effect widens the absorption edge. Cai et al. [86] prepared an artificial photosynthetic alginate (ALG) capsule containing carboxymethyl cellulose matric, red phosphorus quantum dots@g-C3N4 (P/CN) tubular system, and alcohol dehydrogenase via a sol-gel method. As shown in Fig. 17(a) , the chloroplast is a typical cystic structure, mainly composed of a semipermeable membrane and a polysaccharide/protein matrix containing stacked thylakoids and enzymes. Thylakoids in chloroplasts regenerate and supply NADPH under visible-light irradiation. Among them, the basal particles in the P/CN simulated chloroplast regenerate nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) under visible-light irradiation, and continue to provide hydride donors for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH). P/CN enhances the mechanical stability of ALG capsule and inhibits the expansion of ALG capsule, thereby effectively preventing the leaching of ADH and P/CN. As shown in Fig. 17(b), some hollow tubes are observed in the core part of the ADHP/CN@ALG capsule, whose shape and diameter are the same as P/CN tubular system originally added. Triethanolamine (TEOA), [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+(M) and P/CN are chosen as the electron donor, the electron medium and the photocatalyst, respectively, thus simulating the thylakoid in the chloroplast to realize the photocatalysis of NADH regeneration. As exhibited in Fig. 17(c), after the reaction equilibrium, P/CN shows an outstanding NADH regeneration rate of 62.0% under visible-light illumination. In the chloroplast, CO2 reduction and light excitation of the enzyme are separated by the thylakoid membrane to protect the enzyme from light damage, and the tightly coupled photosystem can facilitate electron transfer and promote photocatalysis. By imitating this strategy, Tian et al. [171] constructed a new functional chamber-like inorganic photocatalytic enzyme system for reducing CO2 to formic acid. By coupling Rh complex to TPE-C3N4, NAD+ is effectively reduced to NADH. The tightly bound structure ensures the rapid transfer of electrons to the Rh complex and significantly promotes the regeneration of NADH (Fig. 17(d)). The NADH regeneration rate of the integrated optical system is 9.3 μmol·h−1·min−1, up to 2.33 times compared to the homogeneous system containing TPE-C3N4 and free Rh complex. The inorganic photocatalytic enzyme system can synergistically protect the enzyme and enhance the electron transfer of NADH regeneration, thereby promoting the enhanced photoconversion of CO2 to formic acid. After 9 h of light, 16.75 mM formic acid was produced, up to 3.24 times by contrast with the counterpart produced by homogeneous reaction (Fig. 17(e)). Additionally, inspired by chloroplast particles, Wang et al. [203] designed chloroplast-granum-inspired porous nanorods composed of F-doped g-C3N4 ultrathin nanosheets. Similarly to the cystic membrane of chloroplast particles, the layered nanosheets with porous structure provide a larger specific surface area of 149.40 m2·g−1 and increase the surface for visible-light absorption, while F-doped g-C3N4 nanosheets are conducive to the charge transfer and separation. The H2 production rate of the new photocatalytic system can reach 2600 μmol·g−1·h−1, which is almost 16 times by contrast with g-C3N4 (163 μmol·g−1·h−1). This chloroplast-inspired strategy applies to the conduction of two interacting photocatalytic reactions. Nowadays, it has been expanded into other photocatalytic reactions such as water-splitting for H2 and O2 evolution. In a chloroplast-inspired g-C3N4-based system for photocatalytic water splitting, the cocatalyst for H2 evolution and the cocatalyst for O2 evolution are loaded on the inside and outside surfaces of hollow spherical g-C3N4, respectively [149], thus providing the stable microenvironment and guaranteeing the implementation for H2 and O2 evolution. Additionally, based on the core of this strategy, in some complex organic reactions including three or more interacting reactions that we expected, we can construct three or more independent microenvironments to ensure the successful implementation of efficient and undisturbed reactions. To sum up, the functional bionics is a charming route to improve the photocatalytic reaction efficiency and stability of g-C3N4-based systems. However, the currently developed g-C3N4-based photocatalysts through the functional bionics are limited. Development of new functionally-bionic g-C3N4-based photocatalysts is significant, such as butterfly-wing-inspired system that has excellent light harvesting. 6 Theoretical calculation of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system With the design and synthesis of various bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems, the photocatalytic performances have been improved significantly. However, the key parameters regarding the improved photocatalytic activity are not yet clear, such as the structure-activity relationship, the active sites, the charge-transfer routes, the intermediates and reaction pathways in some complex photocatalytic reactions including CO2 reduction [111,204–207], which are not conducive to researchers’ understanding of the reaction mechanisms related to the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems. The theoretical calculation based on the first-principle density functional theory (DFT) is a powerful tool to reveal the photocatalytic reaction mechanisms. Through theoretical calculations, the electronic structures and properties of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems, the charge-transfer routes, the active sites and reaction pathways can be uncovered, which enable the follow-up researchers to better understand the structure-property relationship of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems and predict the properties of other bio-inspired materials [111,208–211]. This chapter focuses on the theoretical calculations of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems for photocatalytic reactions. It properly consists of three parts, including state density/band structure calculation, differential charge analysis, chemical reaction paths and intermediates. 6.1 State density/band structure calculation of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system The band structures of semiconductor photocatalysts are closely related to their optical properties and redox abilities, which directly affect the excitation and transport of photogenerated charges [120,212–214]. Therefore, the investigation of state density/band structure is of great significance to the photocatalytic mechanism study of g-C3N4-based system. For instance, Feng et al. [186] reported a B-doped leaf-vein-like g-C3N4 with the defects for boosting photocatalytic H2O2 evolution. To understand the effect of defect modification and B-doping on the narrowing bandgap of leaf-vein-like g-C3N4, DFT calculations on the density of states (DOS) were performed. As shown in Fig. 18 , defect modification and B-doping contribute to a downward shift of CB with the narrow bandgap by contrast with g-C3N4. It can be seen from Fig. 18(a) that the VB of g-C3N4 consists of N p orbitals, while the CB is composed of by C p and N p orbitals. However, the energy band of defected g-C3N4 is narrowed due to the introduction of defects (Fig. 18(b)). With the construction of B-doped defected leaf-vein-like g-C3N4, the energy band is further narrowed with an increased contribution of C p orbitals to the CB (Fig. 18(c)). The DFT calculations in this work are beneficial to the in-depth understanding for the follow-up researchers regarding the functions of defects and doping sites on g-C3N4 band structure. Therefore, by rationally analyzing the density of states and energy band structure, scientifically introducing defects or doping heteroatoms can effectively shorten the band-gap width and enhance the photocatalytic performances of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems. 6.2 Differential charge analysis of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system The uncovering of charge-transfer routes is an important aspect for investigating the photocatalytic mechanisms of g-C3N4-based system. Through the differential charge analysis and systematic experimental characterizations, the charge transfer routes of g-C3N4-based system can be revealed, thus contributing to the optimization of charge separation and transfer for bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system [215–218]. For example, Liang et al. [193] take advantage of DFT calculations to investigate the charge difference density in a fish-scale carbon-nitrogen-based tubular system (ZnIn2S4/FTCNso), thus determining the direction of electron transfer. As shown in Fig. 19(a) , the electron density of FTCNso layer nearby ZnIn2S4 reduces, while the electron density of ZnIn2S4 layer nearby FTCNso increases, indicating a charge transfer from FTCNso to ZnIn2S4, thus facilitating the separation and migration of charges. Hu et al. [219] synthesized a flowerlike copper-doped g-C3N4. Based on the DFT simulation of charge density difference, they found the electron depletion and accumulation on the Cu+ doping sites and N2 molecules, respectively (Fig. 19(b)), indicative of the electron transfer from Cu+ doping sites to N2 molecules. Therefore, we can design and construct high-efficiency bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems with fast charge transfer relying on the differential charge analysis. 6.3 Chemical reaction-path calculation of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system The identification and precise regulation of active sites in catalytic reactions has always been the focus. Due to the limitations of experimental characterizations, it is difficult to determine the actual active sites at the atomic/molecular scale. This challenge can be solved by the use of DFT calculations, which have unique advantages in the research of adsorption and activation of the reactant molecules. By analyzing the stable form and model regarding the adsorption process of reactant molecules, the specific positions of the reaction active sites can be preliminarily confirmed, and the optimal thermodynamic route of catalytic reactions can be revealed at the same time, thus providing guidance for the experimental design and synthesis of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system with excellent performance. For instance, Wang et al. [220] demonstrated that the –C≡N groups in g-C3N4 are the active sites for photocatalytic nitrogen reduction through the reaction-path calculations. Wang et al. [221] constructed six-oxygen-coordinated single Ni sites on g-C3N4 with the boron-oxo species. Relying on the reaction-path calculations and diverse in-situ characterizations, they proved that the Ni sites are the active sites for photocatalytic water-activation-induced CO2 reduction. Luo et al. [222] reported a g-C3N4 with nitrogen vacancies (NV) for photocatalytic H2O2 generation. Based on the DFT calculations, it can be found that the NV sites with the accumulated electrons can act as reduction centers, and the N atoms with the accumulated holes can act as oxidation centers. Additionally, DFT calculations can be also used to reveal the reaction paths in some complex photocatalytic reactions, such as photocatalytic CO2 conversion. For example, Li et al. [223] reported a hollow spherical Z-scheme SnS2/g-C3N4/C system (SCC). Using the DFT calculations, it can be concluded that COOH* is easily formed on the SCC and CO is easily desorbed from the SCC surface compared to g-C3N4 (Fig. 20(a) ), indicating that the construction of hollow spherical Z-scheme heterostructure can effectively introduce the active sites for CO2 adsorption and activation. Liu et al. [224] synthesized a functionalized g-C3N4 with carbon vacancy (FCN-V). The DFT results (Fig. 20(b)) suggest that FCN-V is more kinetically favorable to desorb CO* in the rate-determining step by contrast with pure g-C3N4 with carbon vacancy (DCN-V), indicating the reduced energy barriers for CO2 activation and CO desorption. These examples well explain the advantages of DFT calculations in the uncovering of the active sites and reaction paths of photocatalytic reactions over g-C3N4-based materials. The DFT calculations apply equally to the analysis of the active sites and reaction paths regarding the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems, thereby clarifying the photocatalytic mechanisms. 7 Application of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based system The bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems have numerous unique advantages, such as significantly increased surface area and active sites, expansion of light absorption range, accelerated charge separation and transfer, which enable them to be applied in the fields of energy conversion and environmental remediation, including photocatalytic water splitting for H2 generation, photocatalytic pollutant degradation, photocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction, photocatalytic nitrogen reduction, photocatalytic H2O2 production, etc. The applications of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems are briefly introduced as follows. 7.1 Photocatalytic water splitting for H2 generation Hydrogen energy is a renewable energy due to its high energy density, harmlessness to the environment, and high heating value [66,225–228]. For the green production of H2, the solar-driven water splitting for H2 generation over semiconductor photocatalysts under the mild conditions has been considered as a promising strategy [229–232]. Over the past few decades, the key for limiting the improvement of photocatalytic H2 evolution performance still remains the use of suitable photocatalysts. g-C3N4 can be acted as an efficient photocatalyst for H2 evolution due to its appropriate band-gap, outstanding thermal and chemical stability, low cost, and environmental friendliness [233,234]. However, the original bulk g-C3N4 has poor photocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution mainly due to low surface area and easy recombination of charge pairs [235,236]. To improve the photocatalytic H2 evolution performance of g-C3N4, a series of bionic strategies have been proposed to construct the bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems. As shown in Table 2 , the H2 yields of g-C3N4-based systems with different biomimetic structures have been improved significantly owing to the increased surface area and the accelerated charge transfer. However, the structure-activity relationship and photocatalytic reaction mechanism of these bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems are unclear. Therefore, the future research on the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems for photocatalytic H2 evolution would focus on the uncovering of reaction mechanisms. 7.2 Photocatalytic pollutant degradation The environmental pollution has caused a great negative impact on human life and health. It is mainly due to the release of various pollutants that are difficult to be eliminated or degraded relying only on nature [241,242]. Semiconductor photocatalysis is considered to be a high-efficiency, economical and green method to eliminate environmental pollution under the mild conditions [243–246]. In this respect, g-C3N4-based materials have been considered as the promising candidates with the excellent photocatalytic degradation performance [247–251]. Recently, various bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems have been widely used in photodegradation of diverse pollutants, including RhB, MB, BPA, PHBA, Cr (VI), and K2Cr2O7, etc. A comprehensive list of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems for photocatalytic degradation of pollutants is shown in Table 3 . Although the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems have made important progress in the improvement of photocatalytic pollutant degradation activity, the stability is low due to the relatively poor mechanical strength of bio-inspired structures, which limits their practical industrial applications such as the organic wastewater treatment. Therefore, it is advisable to combine with other stable semiconductor materials such as TiO2 to construct the modified bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems for efficient and stable photocatalytic degradation. 7.3 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction and N2 fixation Complex photocatalytic reductions, such as photocatalytic CO2 reduction and photocatalytic N2 fixation, possess numerous reaction pathways and multiple fuel products [6,257–263]. In the two fields, the photocatalysts represented by g-C3N4-based materials have been widely used, however, the low photocatalytic activity and poor product selectivity hinder their practical applications [264–269]. With the design and construction of bio-inspired structures, the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems show the enhanced photocatalytic activity and selectivity (Table 4 ). Nevertheless, the lack of active sites still limits the further improvement of their photocatalytic performance and selectivity. The introduction of active sites through vacancy control, element doping, cocatalyst loading and heterostructure construction is a fascinating path to achieve high conversion efficiency and high selectivity [270–274]. For instance, in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction, the introduction of Cu element in bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems may boost their catalytic activity and selectivity for yielding ethylene, because Cuδ+ is considered to be the active site for the conversion of CO2 to ethylene [275,276]. Except for the wide applications presented above, few bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems have been used in other fields, such as photocatalytic production of H2O2, photocatalytic enzymatic synthesis and so on (Table 4), and display the moderate photocatalytic activity. Even though these applications are in the initial research stage, the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems have the huge potential due to their advantages. We recommend the follow-up researchers to try these applications and even new applications such as solar cell using various bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems in the future, thus advancing the development of bio-inspired nanostructured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts. 8 Modification strategies of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system The bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems show unique advantages in the enhancement of photocatalytic performance. However, the single regulation strategy of bio-inspired design and fabrication cannot achieve the desired photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based system. On this basis of bio-inspired fabrication, coupling other modification means to improve photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4-based system is a promising pathway, such as building various heterojunctions for fast charge separation [279–282], introducing efficient active sites via the loading of single-atom cocatalysts [221,283–285], creating defect sites and constructing doping levels [286–289]. These strategies contribute to excellent catalytic activity and high stability of bio-inspired g-C3N4 photocatalysts, thus enhancing their values in practical applications of photocatalysis. 8.1 Heterojunction construction in bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system The heterojunction construction in bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system via coupling with appropriate semiconductor materials has many advantages regarding the enhancement of photocatalytic activity. Firstly, a built-in electric field is formed based on the heterojunction interface, which can provide the driving force for the fast separation and migration of photoexcited electron-hole pairs, thus leading to the reduction and oxidation reactions taking place on different photocatalyst surface. Secondly, coupling with narrow band-gap semiconductor can effectively utilize the sunlight in the visible and near-infrared regions for bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system [290–292]. Additionally, the heterojunction construction can improve the stability of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system significantly. On account of these advantages, a few heterojunctions based on the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system have been designed and constructed. Taking the heterojunction photocatalysts based on honeycomb-like g-C3N4 as an example, Liang et al. [293] loaded Cd0·5Zn0·5S quantum dots on the surface of honeycomb-like structured g-C3N4 to construct the binary composite (Fig. 21(a) ). With the formation of n-n typed Cd0·5Zn0·5S quantum dots/honeycomb-like g-C3N4 heterojunction (Fig. 21(b)), the spatial separation of charges is accelerated significantly, which is beneficial to the promotion of photocatalytic H2 evolution performance. Li et al. [252] prepared ZnO/g-C3N4 heterojunctions with a honeycomb-like structure via H2 bubble template method (Fig. 21(c)). Due to the formation of the heterojunction interface, the honeycomb-like structured ZnO/g-C3N4 displays higher photocatalytic degradation efficiency of RhB than pure ZnO and g-C3N4 (Fig. 21(d)). These researches indicate that the combination of bio-inspired fabrication and heterojunction construction is conducive to acquire the high photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based photocatalysts. 8.2 Cocatalyst loading in bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system It is noted that cocatalysts play an important role in improving photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based system. The cocatalyst can provide massive active sites for surface reaction, thus boosting the photocatalytic reaction efficiency. Meanwhile, the cocatalyst loading can realize the fast extract of charges and inhibit the reverse reaction between the active species and products. Furthermore, the cocatalyst can consume some needless photogenerated charge, especially for the photogenerated holes, thereby avoiding the photocorrosion oxidation of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based photocatalysts and enhancing their stability [128,294,295]. For example, Sun et al. [253] prepared a bio-inspired flower-like g-C3N4/SnS2 composite via the solvothermal method (Fig. 22(a) ), which exhibits significantly improved Cr (VI) reduction activity under visible-light illumination (Fig. 22(b)). This enhanced photocatalytic activity is due to the effective charge transfer with the cocatalyst loading of SnS2 (Fig. 22(c)). Wu et al. [185] synthesized a GO/g-C3N4/MoS2 flower-like photocatalyst with enhanced photocatalytic reduction performance of Cr (VI) (Fig. 22(d)). This is because the cocatalyst loading of GO and MoS2 contributes to the suppression of charge recombination and the promotion of charge transport (Fig. 22(e)). Huang et al. [255] reported flower-like Co3O4/g-C3N4 system (Figs. 22(f) and (g)). The synergy of the construction of flower-like nanostructure and the introduction of Co3O4 cocatalyst enhances the charge separation and transfer, thus improving the photocatalytic degradation activity of tetracycline under the visible-light illumination (Fig. 22(h)). It is noted that the flower-like structured g-C3N4 has abundant exposed active edges, which can provide massive active sites for reactant molecules as well as accelerate charge separation and transfer. If the nano-sized or quantum-dot-like cocatalyst can be oriented at the edge regions of flower-like g-C3N4, which can maximize the extraction of charges and optimizes the distribution of active sites. 8.3 Defect/doping engineering in bio-inspired g-C3N4-based system Defect/doping engineering is another fascinating approach to enhance the photocatalytic performance of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems significantly. Generally, introducing suitable heteroatoms into the crystal or constructing the lattice defects can effectively increase the adsorption and reaction active sites, thus promoting the catalytic performance of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based photocatalysts. Furthermore, the defect/doping design can reduce the band-gap width of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based photocatalysts and introduces intermediate energy levels, so that the photocatalysts absorb the light with long wavelength and low energy to generate more photoexcited charges [296–299]. At the same time, the defect sites will become shallow potential traps for photoexcited electrons or holes, which can inhibit the recombination of charges and accelerate their motion [216,300–302]. For instance, Zhu et al. [240] synthesized mesoporous P-doped g-C3N4 nanoflowers via the thermal condensation method. The doping of P element can promote light harvesting and charge separation of g-C3N4 nanoflowers, thus yielding the improved photocatalytic H2 evolution activity compared to the original g-C3N4. Hu et al. [219] developed Cu-doped flower-like g-C3N4 via a molten salt-assisted microwave method. The introduction of Cu element activates N2 molecules and promote charge transfer of flower-like g-C3N4, thus leading to 35-fold higher NH4 + evolution rate than that of original g-C3N4. Duan et al. [254] constructed flower-like g-C3N4 with N vacancies via the supramolecular self-assembly method. The presence of N vacancies is in favor of the suppression of charge recombination and the broadening of visible-light response region, thus boosting the photocatalytic activity for NO oxidation of flower-like g-C3N4. Through the modification strategies presented above, the photocatalytic activities of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems have been further enhanced. We can obtain many high-efficiency g-C3N4-based photocatalysts in the future via the combination of bio-inspired design and other modification strategies. This provides a new platform for constructing high-efficiency photocatalysts for various applications. 9 Summary and outlook In summary, the current review has focused on the structure control of g-C3N4-based systems via various preparation methods.
