The structure control is an efficient route to improve solar conversion efficiency and photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based systems. In this review, we first concern on the traditional structures and their effects on the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4-based systems, such as quantum dot, nanotube/nanorod/nanowire/nanofiber, nanosheet, nanosphere, ball-in-ball structure, three-dimensional ordered mesoporous/macroporous structure, three-dimensional ordered close-packed nanosphere array, etc. Apart from these, we pay more attention to bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based systems, which are to mimic the structures of creatures in nature. The bio-inspired design and synthesis of g-C3N4-based systems has focused on two aspects of structural bionics and functional bionics, and the fundamentals of bio-inspired design are introduced in detail. The five kinds of bio-inspired structures regarding structural bionics have been discussed from the aspects of preparation methods, morphologies, photocatalytic activities, photocatalytic mechanism, and the structure-induced effects, including honeycomb-like structure, flower-like structure, fish-scale-like structure, leaf-like structure, and helical-like structure. Similarly, the two kinds of bio-inspired structures regarding functional bionics have been described in detail, including wood-like structure, and chloroplast-inspired structure. These bio-inspired structures of g-C3N4-based systems display distinctive advantages, including abundant potential types, drawing on the functions of creatures, as well as some special and novel properties. Due to the structure-induced advantages of the bio-inspired structures, these bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems have exhibited the improvement of catalytic activity in the applications of photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, photocatalytic water splitting for hydrogen evolution, photocatalytic CO2 reduction, photocatalytic N2 fixation, photocatalytic production of H2O2, photocatalytic enzymatic synthesis, etc. Additionally, to further boost the photocatalytic performance and enhance the potential for practical applications of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems, main modification strategies of bio-inspired g-C3N4-based photocatalysts are described and recapped, such as heterojunction construction, cocatalyst loading, and defect/doping engineering. Despite state-of-the-art advances of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems are grabbed in recent years, there are some major challenges that need to be addressed. (1) The precise control of bio-inspired structures related to g-C3N4-based systems still requires further exploration to obtain optimized and more regular microstructures similarly to the structures of creatures in nature. The similarity of morphology between the structure of targeted creatures and bio-inspired nanostructures is an important factor to the research of bio-inspired structure design. More similarities are beneficial to reveal the structure-induced effect of bio-inspired structures on the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4-based systems. Therefore, it is advisable to design the sophisticated synthesis procedure to efficiently manipulate the morphologies of g-C3N4-based systems and obtain the optimal bio-inspired structures. Some efficient advanced methods are recommended, such as the bio-template method using the components of plants and the bodies of virus or bacteria, and 3D printing method. (2) Currently, most of reported bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems only consider the structural bionics rather than functional bionics. The design of a desired bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based photocatalyst requires the considerations of structural bionics and functional bionics simultaneously. For instance, the design and construction of chloroplast-inspired and enzyme-inspired structures with the independent reaction microenvironments is a promising approach for acquiring efficient bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems. (3) Until now, the bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based systems for photocatalysis is in the initial research stage, and the developed bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems are limited. To develop bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems, except for the chloroplast-inspired and enzyme-inspired structure mentioned above, some special bio-inspired structures that may create new properties for photocatalysis are recommended. For example, the open-up needle-like nanosheet structure with sharp edges such as the sea-urchin-like structure. This structure not only can provide plentiful adsorption and reaction active sites for g-C3N4-based systems, but also induce an unusual charge edge-collection effect, which means that the photoexcited charges selectively transfer and gather at the tips of nanosheets similarly to the lightning rod effect, thus boosting photocatalytic activity significantly [303]. (4) The structure-activity relationship and photocatalytic mechanism of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts need to be clarified, and the exact active sites for photocatalytic reactions in bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems need to be revealed, which are in favor of comprehensive understanding of bio-inspired structure design for the follow-up researchers. To shed light on the photocatalytic mechanisms, some advanced characterizations are recommended. For example, atomic-resolution high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) is a powerful technique to study the atomic environment of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems. Synchrotron-based X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy is beneficial to the analysis of chemical bonding state of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems. Femtosecond-resolved transient absorption spectroscopy (TAS) is a useful means for probing the charge dynamics. Additionally, in situ infrared and in situ Raman spectra can be used to the investigation of intermediates and active sites regarding the photocatalytic reactions. The DFT calculations can be used to investigate the excitation and transfer of photogenerated charges, the active sites and reaction paths of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems. Through various advanced characterizations and theoretical study, the exact active sites, structure-activity relationship and photocatalytic mechanism of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems are expected to be well revealed. (5) Except for photocatalytic water splitting, photocatalytic pollutant degradation, photocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction, photocatalytic nitrogen fixation, photocatalytic H2O2 production, the bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems are the promising candidates for other applications. For example, the chloroplast-inspired g-C3N4-based system can be used in some complex photocatalytic organic synthesis that includes two or more interacting reactions. In chloroplast-inspired system, constructing two or more independent microenvironments is to ensure the successful implementation of the interacting organic reactions. Moreover, the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based systems apply equally to photocatalytic antibacterial and solar battery. For instance, it is likely to be a good choice to construct a sunflower-like structured g-C3N4-based system with the interesting phototropism, which can automatically track the direction of incident light at the range of 0-90o to boost the light absorption efficiency of the solar battery [81]. (6) Other than the photocatalytic activity and stability of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems, many other important parameters need to be considered, such as the product selectivity and conversion rate in photocatalytic CO2 reduction, the solubility and diffusion rate of nitrogen in reaction solutions in photocatalytic N2 fixation, the adsorption rate of reactant molecules and desorption rate of product molecules. These parameters have a major impact on the photocatalytic reaction processes. It is advisable to consider these parameters in the conduction of photocatalytic reactions over bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems. (7) The applications of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts have been limited to the laboratory scale. Once these photocatalysts scale up to the industrial scale, there may be many problems such as the structural damage of catalysts, the decrease of activity and stability, and catalyst poisoning, etc. Therefore, when the bio-inspired g-C3N4-based photocatalysts have achieved outstanding performance in the laboratory scale, it is necessary to invest in catalyst scale-up production research to solve the technological problems, thus advancing the industrialization of biomimetic photocatalysts. In the future, we hope that this review will bring some inspiration for the follow-up researchers in the field of biomimetic photocatalysis. The biomimetic photocatalysis is a new field that faces a lot of problems, and there are few systematic studies on this field so far. To advance the development of biomimetic photocatalysis, we choose g-C3N4-based systems as the research object to well expound the fundamentals of biomimetic photocatalysis, and expand the knowledge on bio-inspired nanostructured g-C3N4-based photocatalysts via providing new perspectives. We are confident that this review is quite distinctive due to the systematical correlation between the bionics and g-C3N4-based photocatalysts, which can encourage the follow-up researchers to try more researches in biomimetic photocatalysis. Guidong Yang is currently a full Professor and the director of XJTU-Oxford International Joint Laboratory for Catalysis in School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, China. He received his Ph.D. degree in Chemical Engineering at China University of Petroleum (East China) in 2010. His current research interests focus on the design and development of novel catalysts for energy and environmental applications including photoelectrocatalytic ammonia synthesis, photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, and porous carbon adsorption materials. He joined the Editorial Board of Chin. J. Catal. in 2021.

coredata.dc:description: As a new organic conjugated semiconductor, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is emerging as a fascinating material for various photocatalytic applications due to its adjustable electronic structure, outstanding thermal endurance, appealing chemical stability, low cost, and environmental friendliness. Nevertheless, unmodified bulk g-C3N4 possesses some intrinsic limitations related to poor crystallinity, marginal visible-light harvesting, easy recombination of charge pairs, small surface area, and slow charge migration, which give rise to the low quantum efficiency of photocatalytic reactions. One efficient strategy to overcome these shortcomings is the manipulation of the microstructures of g-C3N4. Other than the traditional structure control, mimicking the structures of creatures in nature to design and construct bio-inspired structures is a promising approach to improve the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4 and even g-C3N4-based systems. This review summarizes the recent advances of the traditional structure-control of g-C3N4-based systems, and bio-inspired synthesis of g-C3N4-based systems from two aspects of structural bionics and functional bionics. Furthermore, the fundamentals of bio-inspired design and fabrication of g-C3N4-based systems are introduced in detail. Additionally, the different theoretical calculations, diverse photocatalytic applications and various modification strategies of bio-inspired structured g-C3N4-based systems are recapped. We believe that this work will be a guiding star for future research in the new field of biomimetic photocatalysis.
